resources.string: How much fat did it have?
How much protein did it have?
How many carbs did it have?
Word not saved because it is empty.
Calories: 148k Cal | Protein: 23g | Fat: 5g | Cholesterol: 285mg | Sodium: 1180mg | Potassium: 100mg | Vitamin A: 150IU | Vitamin C: 5.2mg | Calcium: 168mg | Iron: 2.5mg
1. Combine oil, chili powder, garlic, lime juice and zest, and salt in a small bowl. Whisk well. Pour over shrimp and let marinate for 20 minutes.
2. Preheat grill. Thread shrimp onto skewers and grill over medium heat, about 2 minutes per side, just until shrimp turn pink.
3. Sprinkle with chopped cilantro and serve.
Prep Time: 20 minutes | | Cook Time: 5 minutes
Calories: 110k Cal | Protein: 2g | Carbs: 26g | Vitamin C: 67% of the Reference Daily Intake (RDI) | Folate: 15% of the RDI | Potassium: 10% of the RDI | Magnesium: 6% of the RDI
How do you like your egg?

1. The key to successful weight loss is developing healthy diet and exercise habits. You may not like those words — diet and exercise. But do not get hung up on them. Diet just means eating healthy, lower calorie meals.
Exercise means being more physically active.

2. Although people appropriately focus on diet when they are trying to lose weight, being active also is an essential component of a weight-loss program. When you are active, your body uses energy (calories) to move, helping to burn the calories you take in with food you eat.

3. Whatever activity you choose, do it regularly. Aim for at least 150 minutes a week of moderate physical activity or 75 minutes a week of vigorous aerobic activity — preferably spread throughout the week. Keep in mind that you may need more physical activity to lose weight and keep it off.
1. Eat a healthy breakfast: If you exercise in the morning, get up early enough to finish breakfast at least one hour before your workout.
2. Watch the food portion size: Be careful not to overdo it when it comes to how much you eat before exercise.
3. Snack well: Snacks eaten soon before exercise probably would not give you added energy if your workout lasts less than 60 minutes, but they may prevent distracting hunger pangs.

4. Eat after you exercise: To help your muscles recover and to replace their glycogen stores, eat a meal that contains both carbohydrates and protein within two hours of your exercise session if possible.
5. Drink up: Do not forget to drink fluids. You need adequate fluids before, during and after exercise to help prevent dehydration.
